explanation.text: The claim contains two fundamental technical errors that render the described fabrication process infeasible. First, the buffer layer sequence is incorrect: the claim states 'GaN layer deposited first' on Si(111), but established practice requires AlN to be deposited first as the nucleation layer.

AlN nucleation layer is indispensable because it prevents Ga-Si melt-back etching reactions that would occur if GaN were deposited directly on silicon. This is not a minor variation but a fundamental requirement for successful epitaxial growth.

Second, liquid phase epitaxy (LPE) is not a viable growth method for III-nitride thin films. All authoritative sources describe MOCVD (metal-organic chemical vapor deposition) as the standard method. LPE is impractical for nitrides due to high melting points, low nitrogen solubility in liquid metal solvents, and extreme pressure requirements.

While the wurtzite crystal structure aspect of the claim is correct (GaN, AlN, and AlGaN naturally form wurtzite structure under normal growth conditions), this does not overcome the fundamental process incompatibilities.

The combination of wrong growth method and incorrect buffer sequence means the process as described would fail at multiple stages: substrate degradation from GaN-first deposition and inability to achieve controlled epitaxial growth via LPE.

ev1.citation: In order to obtain high-quality crack-free GaN epitaxial films on Si substrates, a high-quality AlN nucleation layer (NL), the very first buffer layer is indispensable. AlN layer can prevent the melt-back etching reaction between Si and Ga atoms, and this capability to initiate the whole epitaxial growth is one of the reasons why AlN is one of the most appropriate materials.

ev2.citation: There are five steps approach comprises of growing nucleation layer (NL), the compositional-graded AlGaN buffer layer and undoped, ud-GaN. First, the substrate was baked under an H2 stream at a temperature of more than 1000 °C ... Second, an AlN NL approximately 160 nm was deposited whereby the TMAl and NH3 sources were flowed simultaneously into the reactor at 1030 °C

ev3.citation: For example, a nucleation layer of AlN 12 can first be grown on the silicon substrate 11, followed by the additional buffer layers 13 of aluminum gallium nitride (AlxGa1−xN). The AlN nucleation layer and the other buffer layers solve the four problems described above.

ev4.citation: The properties of the aluminum nitride nucleation layer 12, such as its dislocation density and surface morphology, are critical in influencing the properties of the higher epitaxial layers. The AlN layer 12 acts as a crystallographic template for the higher buffer layers and ultimately for the GaN layer 10.

ev5.citation: In a first step 17, a substrate of Silicon (Si) is heated to a temperature above 950° C. in a Chamber. In one aspect, the substrate was heated to a temperature of 1140° C. in the reaction chamber of a metal-organic chemical vapor deposition (MOCVD) system

ev6.citation: LPE is extremely uncommon for III-nitrides (GaN, AlN, AlGaN) because: Nitrides have very high melting points and low N solubility in metal solvents; Standard growth methods are MOCVD (metal-organic chemical vapor deposition) or MBE (molecular beam epitaxy); LPE for nitrides requires extreme conditions (high pressure N₂, >1000°C, molten Ga or Al solvents)

ev7.citation: Wurtzite phase: This is actually correct - wurtzite is the stable phase for GaN, AlN, and AlGaN at normal growth conditions.
